thread.title: Sheikzayedroad travels back to Woodbine | Horse Racing | Sports | Toronto Sun
thread.title_full: Sheikzayedroad travels back to Woodbine | Horse Racing | Sports | Toronto Sun

author: torontosun.com
title: Sheikzayedroad travels back to Woodbine | Horse Racing | Sports | Toronto Sun
text:
At Thursday’s post-position draw for Sunday’s Canadian International, a lot was made of a horse named for a major thoroughfare in the United Arab Emirates.
When naming the horse, breeder Rabbah Bloodstock could have given him the road’s boring official designation, E 11.
But fortunately for us, though not so fortunately for race callers, he goes by the street’s more attractive name, Sheikhzayedroad.
The six-year-old English-bred son of Dubawi may not be as fancied as the other two runners coming from England for the $1-million turf classic but he does have something they don’t, a win at Woodbine.
Last year, trainer David Simcock tested the waters with him in the Northern Dancer Turf, where he came from last to win by a half-length.
It was believed then that he would return to contest last year’s International but was instead entered in the Queen Elizabeth Stakes at Ascot, where he would be a non-threatening sixth.
“He was always going to go back to Dubai so it would have been three trips,” Simcock said of that decision. “We didn’t want to do that.”
He had been a modest runner when in England but had taken a major race in Dubai in early 2014. He had a second-place finish in Dubai over this past winter before a meddling fifth-place finish in the Dubai Sheema Classic. He was fourth in a Group 1 race at Epsom in June but his form this summer has been mediocre, with only a third-place finish in a minor stake at Chester being his best result.
“We’re pretty happy where he is at the moment,” Ian Russell, Simcock’s assistant who is handling Sheikhzayedroad’s affairs while at Woodbine, said.
“He doesn’t have as much form as he possibly should have but we want to think he’s in the same shape he was when he won the Northern Dancer.”
To get him going, they tried everything including entering him in longer races. But after failing in a two-mile race and one slightly longer than a mile and a half, the plan now is to run him at a distance he is most experienced.
“We played with different distances,” Russell said. “We decided to bring him back to the starting point of a mile and a half.”
Martin Lane will get the ride on Sunday.
BIRD WATCHING
We met him as a two-year-old winning the Coronation Futurity, Canada’s biggest race for two-year-olds.
We watched in 2013 as he won the Breeders’ Stakes then capture Canada’s horse of the year after taking the Jamaica Handicap at Belmont.
Now that he spends most of his time competing in good turf events stateside, we get another look at Up With The Birds as he looks to become the sixth different Canadian-bred to win the International.
“I’ve been very happy with him,” trainer Graham Motion told Woodbine Entertainment.
“He’s doing well. I thought his Arlington Million going a mile and a quarter was very good.”
However that fourth-place finish behind Chicago favourite The Pizza Man may have been his best U.S. outing.
This season, he has thirds in the Dixie at Pimlico and in the Arlington Handicap and another fourth in his last start, the Commonwealth Cup at Laurel.
Last year, he won his only local start, the Nijinsky Stakes.
But he ended his season with a trip to the Japan Cup, a race he was by no means competitive in.
John Velazquez comes north for the mount.
TRYING AGAIN
The first attempt at open company by Danish Dynaformer was not that good.
He found himself on the lead early in the Northern Dancer Turf and was a non-factor in the stretch, finishing sixth.
The three-year-old son of Dynaformer will try again in the International as the lone three-year-old in the field, hoping the pace will be more suitable. But the forecast calls for some precipitation meaning the ground will not be as hard as he likes.
Still, there is plenty trainer Roger Attfield likes about the colt that nearly won this year’s Queen’s Plate and impressed all of us with his sensational win in the Breeders’ Stakes.
“He’s got a big turn of foot and a huge cruising speed,” Attfield said. “This is going to be his toughest race so far.”
“He’s doing well heading into it. He’s done well on this course in the past.”
With regular rider Patrick Husbands taking the call on Kaigun, Eurico Rosa da Silva gets the mount.
SATURDAY NOTES
Southern Ring, who dominated in her second lifetime start, should be favoured in the $100,000 Ruling Angel Stakes at Woodbine. Da Silva gets the call … Breeders’ Crown elimination action continues at Woodbine on Saturday night with three-year-olds and older horses looking for spots in the finals.
